sect1.title: Booting 64-Bit Client Images
sect1.para: Branches that only use either 64-bit or 32-bit images require no additional configuration.
Mixed branches are configured as described in .

The default scDistributionContainer LDAP object is used for the first boot of terminals with undetermined architecture. This object must contain the 32-bit SLE11 kernel that can be booted on both 32-bit and 64-bit clients.
If the terminal fails to boot the default 32-bit SLE11-based image, the initial boot can be done via USB using a special image (see for further info):

Alternatively, it is possible to manually create an scWorkstation object in the LDAP database prior to the first boot. The scWorkstation entry must point to the 64-bit SLE12-based image in the custom scDistributionContainer LDAP object.
The boot process with the custom scDistributionContainer LDAP object consists of the following steps:

step.para: The terminal boots the 32-bit SLE11-based boot image.
The terminal is registered. This creates the scWorkstation object in the LDAP database and the config.MAC file.
The generated config.MAC file points to the 64-bit SLE12-based image in the custom scDistributionContainer LDAP object.
Kernel parameters (including version) are compared, and the terminal is then rebooted. If the /srv/SLEPOS service partition is configured, the new boot image is started via Kexec.
The client boots the 64-bit SLE12-based boot image.
The SLE12-based system image is activated and booted.

sect2.title: Dealing with Boot-Related Issues

If booting the POS client failed with an error message stating that the vga=0x314 option is deprecated, there are two ways to fix the problem. For the SLE12-based branch, remove the vga=0x314 kernel parameter from the posdefaults object in the LDAP database using the posAdmin tool. For mixed branches, the vga=0x314 kernel parameter should be removed from the posdefaults object and added to each SLE11-based boot image via the scDistributionContainer object.
